Materials Genomics
Lecture 1: Introduction

Prof. Dr. Philipp Pelz

FAU Erlangen-Nürnberg

Institute of Micro- and Nanostructure Research

Welcome

Week 1 — What is Materials Genomics?

Goals for today:

  • Understand why a “genomics” framing is used in materials science
  • Learn the analogy: genes ↔︎ atoms, genotype ↔︎ structure, phenotype ↔︎ properties
  • See the historical development of key materials databases
  • Connect Materials Genomics to the PSPP framework (from the structure-first viewpoint)

Outline

  1. Why a “genomics” framework?
  2. Genomics analogy for materials
  3. Key databases and their impact
  4. PSPP from a structure-first perspective
  5. Example genomics workflows
  6. Wrap-up & discussion

1. Why Materials Genomics?

Materials science faces:

  • A combinatorial explosion of possible compounds (~10⁵⁰+)
  • Complex, high-dimensional structure–property relationships
  • Slow, expensive traditional experimentation
  • Increasing demand for rapid materials discovery

Modern solutions:

  • High-throughput computation
  • Large curated databases
  • ML models that map structure → properties
  • Automated workflows for screening and design

Materials Genomics provides the systematic, data-centered approach to explore this enormous materials space.

The Big Idea

Just as biology shifted from:

  • Single-gene experiments → entire genome sequencing

  • materials science moves from:

  • Single-material intuition → high-throughput exploration of materials space.

Materials Genomics =
encode structures digitally → compute properties → build predictive models → guide discovery.

2. The Genomics Analogy

Biological genomics

  • Genome = ordered sequence of nucleotides
  • Genotype → phenotype
  • Mutations change function
  • High-throughput sequencing enables search across massive spaces

Materials genomics

  • “Genome” = atomic arrangement + chemical species
  • “Genotype” = crystal structure, symmetry, coordination
  • “Phenotype” = properties (band gap, strength, conductivity)
  • “Mutations” = alloying, doping, distortions, substitutions
  • “Sequencing” = high-throughput DFT or automated experiments

Key Insight

Structure encodes function.
Atoms + positions = information code
Properties = emergent behavior
Tasks:

  • Decode structure → property
  • Search structure space for desired property
  • Predict which new structures will perform well

This analogy frames the rest of the course.

3. Historical Development of Materials Databases

Materials Genomics depends on large, curated databases.

AFLOW

  • Among the first automated high-throughput DFT frameworks
  • Standardized workflows (elastic tensors, charges, hull stability)
  • Enabled combinatorial exploration of structure + chemistry

OQMD

  • Massive DFT dataset (over 1 million structures)
  • Focused on formation energies and stability
  • Enabled systematic phase diagram construction
  • Essential for alloy and multi-component systems

Materials Project

  • Brought high-throughput DFT to the public
  • Easy search interfaces + API access
  • Elastic tensors, band structures, phase diagrams, dielectric constants
  • A major teaching and prototyping resource

NOMAD

  • FAIR repository for raw computational output
  • Emphasis on interoperability across codes
  • European ecosystem for reproducible materials data
  • Enables large-scale ML by unifying formats and metadata

Why These Databases Matter

They provide: - Large training sets
- Standardization & reproducibility
- Public benchmarks
- Shared infrastructure for ML research
- A common language for the community

Without them, Materials Genomics would not exist as a field.

4. PSPP From a Structure-First Perspective

Processing → Structure → Properties → Performance
(Your ML course focused on processing-first.)

Materials Genomics works backwards:

  1. Desired performance
    e.g., optical transparency, catalytic activity, conductivity

  2. Required properties
    band gap, adsorption energies, activation barriers

  3. Candidate structures
    perovskites, Heuslers, spinels, MXenes, zeolites

  4. Processing routes
    how to synthesize them in reality

Structure as the Information Layer

Central idea: Structure determines properties more directly than processing.

Thus Materials Genomics focuses heavily on: - Representation of structure
- Descriptors/featurization
- Predictive models
- Screening across structural families

5. Example Genomics Workflows

Example 1 — Band Gap Prediction

  1. Encode structure
  2. Extract features
  3. Train ML model
  4. Predict band gaps for thousands of candidates
  5. Select promising materials for synthesis

Example 2 — Phase Stability Screening

  1. High-throughput DFT: formation energies
  2. Construct convex hull
  3. Identify stable and near-stable materials
  4. Propose synthesis targets

Example 3 — Fast-Ion Conductors

  1. Analyze local coordination networks
  2. Estimate migration pathways
  3. Predict ionic conductivity via ML
  4. Explore chemical substitutions

Example 4 — Catalysis Discovery

  1. Compute adsorption energies for surface sites
  2. Use ML to map composition → adsorption
  3. Construct volcano plots
  4. Identify optimal catalytic compositions

What These Examples Teach

  • Genomics is systematic, not anecdotal
  • It works because structure can be encoded digitally
  • ML accelerates screening
  • Computation guides experiment
  • High-throughput workflows replace trial-and-error

6. Wrap-Up

Key insights from today:

  • Materials Genomics = data-rich, structure-centered discovery
  • The genomics analogy frames structure–property reasoning
  • AFLOW, OQMD, Materials Project, NOMAD built the modern ecosystem
  • PSPP can be inverted: performance → properties → structure
  • Sets the stage for Weeks 2–14: descriptors, ML models, surrogate design, and autonomous discovery

Discussion

Questions to consider: - Where does the genomics analogy break down?
- What limits high-throughput computation today?
- How might autonomous labs close the loop between prediction and experiment?
